body: I cannot find such an instance.

There was a thread on beam-dev where I think we decided that if the user wants to customize the combine transform, they can do it by applying Combine themselves to the CombineFn. E.g. `Combine.globally(Count.combineFn()).withoutDefaults()`.

https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/f448eb9f531bec2c0cd70e790dc8d2198d8a1bf9d2b85f94d9ac904a@%3Cdev.beam.apache.org%3E

Thanks for fixing this, @JingsongLi ðŸ˜ƒ 

Now, on to the other PRs ...

I don't read that thread as having clear consensus. However
(especially looking at this with fresh eyes) I still think having to
turn

      Count.globally()

into

      Combine.globally(Count.combineFn()).withoutDefaults()

instead of

      Count.globally().withoutDefaults()

to set the option is neither intuitive nor clean. We should either get
rid of globally() or have it return something (maybe Combine.Globally,
maybe a more restricted interface) that does allow setting options for
consistency.


On Thu, Apr 20, 2017 at 9:02 AM, Eugene Kirpichov
<notifications@github.com> wrote:
> There was a thread on beam-dev where I think we decided that if the user
> wants to customize the combine transform, they can do it by applying Combine
> themselves to the CombineFn. E.g.
> Combine.globally(Count.combineFn()).withoutDefaults().
>
> https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/f448eb9f531bec2c0cd70e790dc8d2198d8a1bf9d2b85f94d9ac904a@%3Cdev.beam.apache.org%3E
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

IMO unless `Count` is deprecated, I don't think it's clear enough for developers, to choose `Count.globally()` for GlobalWindow, but need to have `Combine.globally(Count.combineFn()).withoutDefaults()` for other windows.

Thanks for doing this. In terms of naming, all values are OutputValue, even the main one--could we call this TaggedOutput instead. Thus one would write, e.g.

```
def process(element):
    yield element + 1 # main
    yield TaggedOutput(element + 2) # non-main
```

R: @bjchambers

I agree that if `withoutDefaults` is a very common case, then requiring users to write `Combine.globally(Count.combineFn()).withoutDefaults()` is inconvenient.

I'm also fine with:
- having a `Count.globallyWithoutDefaults()` method
- having Count.globally() return a custom `Count.Globally` transform, which has a `withoutDefaults()` builder method (and under the hood, I suppose, expands into a `Combine.globally()`)

What I'm still strongly against is returning a `Combine.Globally` because, as discussed on the thread that violates the abstraction boundary between the user of `Count` and its implementation by promising that `Count.globally()` will always, forever, be implemented exactly as a single application of the `Combine.Globally` transform.

On Thu, Apr 20, 2017 at 11:46 AM, Eugene Kirpichov <notifications@github.com
> wrote:

> I agree that if withoutDefaults is a very common case, then requiring
> users to write Combine.globally(Count.combineFn()).withoutDefaults() is
> inconvenient.
>
> I'm also fine with:
>
>    - having a Count.globallyWithoutDefaults() method
>
>
And Count.globallyAsSingletonView(), Count.globallyWithFanout(),
Count.globallyWithFanoutWithoutDefaults(),
etc.? Similarly with
{Sum,Max,Min,Mean,...}.{integers,doubles,longs}GloballyXxx?


>    - having Count.globally() return a custom Count.Globally transform,
>    which has a withoutDefaults() builder method (and under the hood, I
>    suppose, expands into a Combine.globally())
>
> Again, one has the issue that that this wrapper class would need to
implement all of these methods, as would the wrapper classes for all the
other global combines we offer.

>
>
> What I'm still strongly against is returning a Combine.Globally because,
> as discussed on the thread that violates the abstraction boundary between
> the user of Count and its implementation by promising that
> Count.globally() will always, forever, be implemented exactly as a single
> application of the Combine.Globally transform.
>
That depends on where the abstraction boundary lives. Is this a convenience
wrapper or an opaque transform? Hiding information like this avoids the
natural composability, forcing one to manually implement a cross product.
Instead one can see it as a feature that features added to CombineGlobally
are automatically available to Count.globally().

The third alternative is to introduce an interface which Combine.Globally
implements, but has all these "global combine-y" methods. The declared
return type would be this interface, the actual returned object would be a
Combine.Globally.

The only option that really doesn't makes sense is "with side inputs."
Technically, I think side inputs could be bond to the [Proto]CombineFn to
get a CombineFn rather than being attached when constructing the operation
(and similarly for DoFns) which solves the issue that the set (if any) of
valid side inputs is a property of the Fn not the Transform, but that's a
much more invasive API.

Perhaps this should be taken to the list?

What is incorrect about it? I didn't handle KafkaIO port to Beam's expand() API, but it looks like Reader.expand() decides weather it would be bounded source or unbounded.

.apply() calls .expand() under the hood. Manually calling .expand() is always a bug because it bypasses a lot of important transform application machinery in the runner. See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-438

@davor updated the PR, PTAL.

This changes moves the copying piece to the root pom.xml. At root level these two files needed for Python packaging (LICENSE and NOTICE) pushed down to the right folder.

One may ask, why are we not packaging python at root instead of pushing down these files. The reason is we need to execute `setup.py` for packaging. The resulting package could only contain files that exist in the same sub-directory tree as the location of `setup.py`. And building the python package at root would require copying the whole `sdks/python` path to root.

Another question would be, what happens if `mvn` is invoked directly as `sdks/python` directory. In this case, packaging will succeed however resulting artifacts would not have the necessary files. This should not be a problem since our release procedure requires running `mvn` at root for packaging all needed artifacts.

Actually, because `GlobalWindow.Coder` and `IntervalWindowCoder` are both `StandardCoders` and are `consistentWithEquals`, their structural values will be the input window regardless. I'm going to revert that part of the change. I can add a comment to note that behavior.
